Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```
I'll analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file to help future instances of Claude Code work effectively in this repository.

# ğŸš€ Modern React TypeScript Template A production-ready template featuring Firebase authentication, advanced testing infrastructure, CI/CD automation, and intelligent LLM context management. ## âœ¨ Features ### Core Stack - **React 19** + **TypeScript** - Latest React with full type safety - **Vite** - Lightning-fast build tooling - **Tailwind CSS** - Utility-first styling - **Zustand** - Lightweight state management - **Firebase** - Authentication & Firestore database ### Testing Infrastructure - **Vitest** - Unit testing with React Testing Library - **Playwright** - E2E testing across browsers - **Storybook** - Component development & visual testing - **Coverage Reports** - Configured for 90%+ target ### Developer Experience - **Environment Validation** - Type-safe environment variables - **LLM Context Management** - RAG system for intelligent code assistance - **Cursor Rules** - Development guidelines and patterns - **CI/CD Workflows** - GitHub Actions with quality gates - **Hot Module Replacement** - Instant development feedback - **Absolute Imports** - Clean import paths with `@/` alias ### Security & Quality - **Secure Configuration** - No hardcoded secrets - **Type Safety** - Strict TypeScript configuration - **ESLint & Prettier** - Code quality and formatting - **Git Hooks** - Pre-commit quality checks ## ğŸš§ Planned Features The following features are documented but **not yet implemented**: - Advanced learning analytics system - Knowledge extraction and Anki integration - Automated retrospectives - Ledger automation for progress tracking - Full security scanning pipeline (partial implementation) ## ğŸš€ Quick Start ### Prerequisites - Node.js 18+ - npm or yarn ### Setup 1. **Clone the template** ```bash git clone https://github.com/yourusername/template-name.git my-app cd my-app ``` 2. **Install dependencies** ```bash npm install ``` 3. **Start with Firebase Emulators (Recommended for Development)** ```bash # Start both emulators and dev server npm run dev:emulators # Or start them separately npm run emulators # Terminal 1 npm run dev # Terminal 2 ``` **âœ… No Firebase project setup required!** The app works immediately with local emulators. **Emulator UI**: Visit `http://localhost:4000` to manage data, users, and functions. 4. **Alternative: Configure Real Firebase (Optional)** If you prefer to use a real Firebase project: a. Create a new Firebase project at [console.firebase.google.com](https://console.firebase.google.com) b. Enable Authentication and Firestore c. Update `.env` file: ```bash # Set to false to use real Firebase VITE_USE_EMULATOR=false # Add your real Firebase credentials VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your_real_api_key VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your_real_auth_domain # ... etc ``` 5. **Run tests** ```bash npm test # Unit tests npm run test:e2e # E2E tests npm run storybook # Component development ``` ### ğŸ¯ What You Get Out of the Box With emulators running, you can immediately: - âœ… **Sign up/Sign in** with any email (no verification needed) - âœ… **Create, edit, delete** sample items in the dashboard - âœ… **Switch themes** (light/dark mode) - âœ… **View data** in the Firebase Emulator UI - âœ… **Test Firebase Functions** locally - âœ… **Import/export** test data ### ğŸ“– Learn More - **[Firebase Emulators Guide](docs/FIREBASE_EMULATORS.md)** - Complete emulator setup and usage - **[Architecture Overview](docs/02_architecture.md)** - Technical design decisions - **[Development Workflow](Workflow_Idea.md)** - Structured development process ## ğŸ“ Project Structure ``` src/ â”œâ”€â”€ agents/ # LLM context management â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ context.ts # Project context for AI assistance â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ prompt_helpers.ts # Prompt generation utilities â”‚ â””â”€â”€ rag_system.ts # Intelligent code retrieval â”œâ”€â”€ components/ # React components â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ SampleCard.tsx # Example card component â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ SampleList.tsx # Example list component â”‚ â””â”€â”€ ProtectedRoute.tsx # Auth protection wrapper â”œâ”€â”€ lib/ # Utilities and configs â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ firebase.ts # Firebase initialization â”‚ â””â”€â”€ utils.ts # Helper functions â”œâ”€â”€ pages/ # Page components â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ Dashboard.tsx # Main app page â”‚ â””â”€â”€ Login.tsx # Authentication page â”œâ”€â”€ store/ # Zustand stores â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ authStore.ts # Authentication state â”‚ â””â”€â”€ appStore.ts # Application state â”œâ”€â”€ test/ # Test utilities â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ setup.ts # Test configuration â”‚ â””â”€â”€ utils.tsx # Test helpers â””â”€â”€ types/ # TypeScript definitions ``` ## ğŸ”§ Configuration ### Environment Variables Create a `.env` file with: ```env # Firebase Configuration VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your_api_key VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your_auth_domain VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=your_project_id VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=your_storage_bucket VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=your_sender_id VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID=your_app_id # Optional: Analytics VITE_FIREBASE_MEASUREMENT_ID=your_measurement_id ``` ### Firebase Security Rules Update `firestore.rules` for your data model: ```javascript rules_version = '2'; service cloud.firestore { match /databases/{database}/documents { // Users can only access their own data match /users/{userId} { allow read, write: if request.auth != null && request.auth.uid == userId; } // Add your custom rules here } } ``` ## ğŸ§ª Testing ### Unit Tests (Vitest) ```bash npm test # Run tests in watch mode npm run test:run # Run once npm run test:coverage # Generate coverage report ``` ### E2E Tests (Playwright) ```bash npm run test:e2e # Run headless npm run test:e2e:headed # Run with browser UI npm run test:e2e:ui # Open Playwright UI ``` ### Component Development (Storybook) ```bash npm run storybook # Start Storybook dev server npm run build-storybook # Build static Storybook ``` ## ğŸš€ Deployment ### GitHub Actions CI/CD The template includes workflows for: - **Continuous Integration** - Tests on every push - **Pull Request Checks** - Quality gates for PRs - **Storybook Deployment** - Auto-deploy to GitHub Pages ### Manual Deployment 1. **Build the app** ```bash npm run build ``` 2. **Deploy to Firebase Hosting** ```bash npm install -g firebase-tools firebase login firebase init hosting firebase deploy ``` 3. **Deploy to Vercel** ```bash npm install -g vercel vercel ``` ## ğŸ¨ Customization Guide ### Adding New Components 1. Create component file: ```typescript // src/components/MyComponent.tsx import { FC } from 'react'; interface MyComponentProps { title: string; } export const MyComponent: FC = ({ title }) => { return
{title}
; }; ``` 2. Add tests: ```typescript // src/components/MyComponent.test.tsx import { render, screen } from '@/test/utils'; import { MyComponent } from './MyComponent'; describe('MyComponent', () => { it('renders title', () => { render(); expect(screen.getByText('Test')).toBeInTheDocument(); }); }); ``` 3. Add Storybook story: ```typescript // src/components/MyComponent.stories.tsx import type { Meta, StoryObj } from '@storybook/react'; import { MyComponent } from './MyComponent'; const meta: Meta = { title: 'Components/MyComponent', component: MyComponent, }; export default meta; export const Default: StoryObj = { args: { title: 'Hello World', }, }; ``` ### Extending Authentication The template uses Firebase Auth with email/password by default. To add providers: ```typescript // src/lib/firebase.ts import { GoogleAuthProvider, signInWithPopup } from 'firebase/auth'; export const signInWithGoogle = async () => { const provider = new GoogleAuthProvider(); return signInWithPopup(auth, provider); }; ``` ### State Management Create new stores with Zustand: ```typescript // src/store/myStore.ts import { create } from 'zustand'; interface MyStore { count: number; increment: () => void; decrement: () => void; } export const useMyStore = create((set) => ({ count: 0, increment: () => set((state) => ({ count: state.count + 1 })), decrement: () => set((state) => ({ count: state.count - 1 })), })); ``` ## ğŸ¤– LLM Context Management ### Using the RAG System ```typescript import { ragSystem } from '@/agents/rag_system'; // Search for relevant code context const results = await ragSystem.search('authentication flow'); // Generate context-aware prompts const prompt = await ragSystem.generatePrompt( 'How do I add social login?', 'CODE_ANALYSIS' ); ``` ### Prompt Templates ```typescript import { PromptBuilder } from '@/agents/prompt_helpers'; const builder = new PromptBuilder(); const prompt = builder .setTemplate('CODE_REVIEW') .setContext({ file: 'MyComponent.tsx' }) .addSection('requirements', 'Check for accessibility') .build(); ``` ## ğŸ“š Architecture Decisions ### Why Firebase? - **Simplicity**: Easy setup with powerful features - **Scalability**: Handles growth from prototype to production - **Real-time**: Built-in real-time synchronization - **Security**: Robust security rules system ### Why Zustand? - **Lightweight**: ~8KB bundle size - **Simple API**: No boilerplate or providers - **TypeScript**: Excellent TypeScript support - **DevTools**: Redux DevTools compatible ### Why Vite? - **Speed**: Instant HMR and fast builds - **Modern**: Native ES modules support - **Flexible**: Easy configuration and plugins - **Ecosystem**: Great integration with React ecosystem ## ğŸ› ï¸ Troubleshooting ### Common Issues **Firebase Connection Error** - Check `.env` file has correct credentials - Ensure Firebase project has Authentication enabled - Verify Firestore database is created **Test Failures** - Run `npm install` to ensure all dependencies are installed - Clear test cache: `npm run test -- --clearCache` - Check for console errors in test output **Build Errors** - Clear node_modules: `rm -rf node_modules && npm install` - Check TypeScript errors: `npm run type-check` - Verify all environment variables are set ## ğŸ¤ Contributing 1. Fork the repository 2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`) 3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`) 4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`) 5. Open a Pull Request ## ğŸ“„ License This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details. ## ğŸ™ Acknowledgments - React team for the amazing framework - Firebase team for the backend infrastructure - Testing library maintainers - Open source community --- Built with â¤ï¸ for modern web development

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Essential Commands

### Development
```bash
npm install                    # Install dependencies
npm run dev                    # Start development server
npm run dev:emulators         # Start with Firebase emulators (recommended)
npm run build                 # Build for production
npm run lint                  # Run ESLint
```

### Testing
```bash
npm test                      # Run unit tests in watch mode
npm run test:run              # Run unit tests once
npm run test:coverage         # Generate coverage report
npm run test:e2e              # Run Playwright E2E tests
npm run test:e2e:ui          # Run E2E tests with UI
npm run storybook             # Start Storybook for component development
```

### Firebase Emulators
```bash
npm run emulators             # Start Firebase emulators
npm run emulators:export      # Export emulator data
npm run emulators:import      # Import emulator data
```

The app works immediately with Firebase emulators - no Firebase project setup required for development.

## Architecture Overview

This is a modern React TypeScript template with Firebase backend, featuring:

### Core Stack
- **React 19** with **TypeScript** - Latest React with strict type safety
- **Vite** - Fast build tooling with HMR
- **Tailwind CSS** - Utility-first styling
- **Zustand** - Lightweight state management
- **Firebase** - Authentication, Firestore database, Functions

### Key Components
- **Authentication**: Email/password and Google OAuth via `src/store/authStore.ts`
- **Firebase Config**: Environment-aware setup in `src/lib/firebase.ts` with emulator support
- **State Management**: Zustand stores in `src/store/` for auth and app state
- **Component Library**: Tested components in `src/components/` with Storybook stories
- **Protected Routes**: Auth-gated pages using `src/components/ProtectedRoute.tsx`

### Project Structure
```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ components/          # React components with tests and stories
â”œâ”€â”€ lib/                # Utilities (firebase.ts, env.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ pages/              # Page components (Dashboard.tsx, Login.tsx)
â”œâ”€â”€ store/              # Zustand stores (authStore.ts, appStore.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ test/               # Test utilities and setup
â””â”€â”€ types/              # TypeScript type definitions
```

### Testing Infrastructure
- **Vitest** - Unit testing with React Testing Library
- **Playwright** - E2E testing across browsers 
- **Storybook** - Component development and visual testing
- Configured for 90%+ test coverage targets

### Environment Configuration
- Uses type-safe environment validation via `src/lib/env.ts`
- Supports both Firebase emulators and real Firebase projects
- Set `VITE_USE_EMULATOR=true` for local development (default)

### Firebase Emulator Setup
- **Auth**: Port 9099
- **Firestore**: Port 8088  
- **Functions**: Port 5001
- **UI**: Port 4000 (management interface)

### Key Features
- Automatic Firebase emulator connection in development
- Type-safe environment variable handling
- Comprehensive error handling with user-friendly messages
- Real-time Firestore integration
- Responsive design with dark/light mode support
- CI/CD ready with GitHub Actions workflows

### Development Workflow
This project follows a structured development approach:
1. Architecture-first design with system documentation
2. MVP slicing with iterative delivery
3. Automatic feedback via CI/CD
4. Test-driven development for critical paths

### Important Notes
- Always run tests and lint before committing
- Use Firebase emulators for development to avoid affecting production data
- Follow the existing TypeScript strict mode conventions
- Components should include tests and Storybook stories
- Environment variables are validated on startup

# Architecture Template

## Data Model

```mermaid
erDiagram
    User ||--o{ Item : creates
    
    User {
        string id PK
        string email
        timestamp createdAt
        timestamp updatedAt
    }
    
    Item {
        string id PK
        string userId FK
        string name
        string description
        json metadata
    }
```

## Core User Flow

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant U as User
    participant F as Frontend
    participant A as API
    participant DB as Database
    
    U->>F: Register / Login
    F->>A: Authentication Request
    A->>DB: Create/Verify User
    A-->>F: Auth Success (JWT/Session)
    
    U->>F: View Dashboard
    F->>A: Fetch Items
    A->>DB: Get Items for User
    DB-->>A: Item List
    A-->>F: Return Items
    
    U->>F: Create New Item
    F->>F: Update UI (Optimistic)
    F->>A: Save Item
    A-->>DB: Store Item
    A-->>F: Confirm Save
```

## Tech Stack

### Frontend
- **React + TypeScript** - Type-safe component development
- **Vite** - Fast build tooling
- **Zustand** - State management for drag-drop state
- **@dnd-kit** - Accessible drag-and-drop
- **Tailwind CSS** - Utility-first styling
- **React Query** - Data fetching & caching

### Backend
- **Firebase Functions** - Serverless functions
- **Firestore** - NoSQL document database
- **Firebase Auth** - Authentication service

### Infrastructure
- **Vercel** - Frontend hosting
- **Firebase** - Backend services
- **GitHub Actions** - CI/CD

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Optimistic UI Updates**: User actions feel instant, with background synchronization.
2. **Component-Based Architecture**: Promotes reusability and separation of concerns.
3. **Scalable Backend**: Serverless architecture for scalability and cost-effectiveness.
4. **API Caching**: Reduces latency and improves performance.

## Security Considerations

- Secure handling of authentication tokens/sessions.
- Database security rules to control data access.
- API rate limiting to prevent abuse.
- CORS restricted to the application domain.

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Essential Commands

### Development
```bash
npm install                    # Install dependencies
npm run dev                    # Start development server
npm run dev:emulators         # Start with Firebase emulators (recommended)
npm run build                 # Build for production
npm run lint                  # Run ESLint
```

### Testing
```bash
npm test                      # Run unit tests in watch mode
npm run test:run              # Run unit tests once
npm run test:coverage         # Generate coverage report
npm run test:e2e              # Run Playwright E2E tests
npm run test:e2e:ui          # Run E2E tests with UI
npm run storybook             # Start Storybook for component development
```

### Firebase Emulators
```bash
npm run emulators             # Start Firebase emulators
npm run emulators:export      # Export emulator data
npm run emulators:import      # Import emulator data
```

The app works immediately with Firebase emulators - no Firebase project setup required for development.

## Architecture Overview

This is a modern React TypeScript template with Firebase backend, featuring:

### Core Stack
- **React 19** with **TypeScript** - Latest React with strict type safety
- **Vite** - Fast build tooling with HMR
- **Tailwind CSS** - Utility-first styling
- **Zustand** - Lightweight state management
- **Firebase** - Authentication, Firestore database, Functions

### Key Components
- **Authentication**: Email/password and Google OAuth via `src/store/authStore.ts`
- **Firebase Config**: Environment-aware setup in `src/lib/firebase.ts` with emulator support
- **State Management**: Zustand stores in `src/store/` for auth and app state
- **Component Library**: Tested components in `src/components/` with Storybook stories
- **Protected Routes**: Auth-gated pages using `src/components/ProtectedRoute.tsx`

### Project Structure
```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ components/          # React components with tests and stories
â”œâ”€â”€ lib/                # Utilities (firebase.ts, env.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ pages/              # Page components (Dashboard.tsx, Login.tsx)
â”œâ”€â”€ store/              # Zustand stores (authStore.ts, appStore.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ test/               # Test utilities and setup
â””â”€â”€ types/              # TypeScript type definitions
```

### Testing Infrastructure
- **Vitest** - Unit testing with React Testing Library
- **Playwright** - E2E testing across browsers 
- **Storybook** - Component development and visual testing
- Configured for 90%+ test coverage targets

### Environment Configuration
- Uses type-safe environment validation via `src/lib/env.ts`
- Supports both Firebase emulators and real Firebase projects
- Set `VITE_USE_EMULATOR=true` for local development (default)

### Firebase Emulator Setup
- **Auth**: Port 9099
- **Firestore**: Port 8088  
- **Functions**: Port 5001
- **UI**: Port 4000 (management interface)

### Key Features
- Automatic Firebase emulator connection in development
- Type-safe environment variable handling
- Comprehensive error handling with user-friendly messages
- Real-time Firestore integration
- Responsive design with dark/light mode support
- CI/CD ready with GitHub Actions workflows

### Development Workflow
This project follows a structured development approach:
1. Architecture-first design with system documentation
2. MVP slicing with iterative delivery
3. Automatic feedback via CI/CD
4. Test-driven development for critical paths

### Important Notes
- Always run tests and lint before committing
- Use Firebase emulators for development to avoid affecting production data
- Follow the existing TypeScript strict mode conventions
- Components should include tests and Storybook stories
- Environment variables are validated on startup

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Essential Commands

### Development
```bash
npm install                    # Install dependencies
npm run dev                    # Start development server
npm run dev:emulators         # Start with Firebase emulators (recommended)
npm run build                 # Build for production
npm run lint                  # Run ESLint
```

### Testing
```bash
npm test                      # Run unit tests in watch mode
npm run test:run              # Run unit tests once
npm run test:coverage         # Generate coverage report
npm run test:e2e              # Run Playwright E2E tests
npm run test:e2e:ui          # Run E2E tests with UI
npm run storybook             # Start Storybook for component development
```

### Firebase Emulators
```bash
npm run emulators             # Start Firebase emulators
npm run emulators:export      # Export emulator data
npm run emulators:import      # Import emulator data
```

The app works immediately with Firebase emulators - no Firebase project setup required for development.

## Architecture Overview

This is a modern React TypeScript template with Firebase backend, featuring:

### Core Stack
- **React 19** with **TypeScript** - Latest React with strict type safety
- **Vite** - Fast build tooling with HMR
- **Tailwind CSS** - Utility-first styling
- **Zustand** - Lightweight state management
- **Firebase** - Authentication, Firestore database, Functions

### Key Components
- **Authentication**: Email/password and Google OAuth via `src/store/authStore.ts`
- **Firebase Config**: Environment-aware setup in `src/lib/firebase.ts` with emulator support
- **State Management**: Zustand stores in `src/store/` for auth and app state
- **Component Library**: Tested components in `src/components/` with Storybook stories
- **Protected Routes**: Auth-gated pages using `src/components/ProtectedRoute.tsx`

### Project Structure
```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ components/          # React components with tests and stories
â”œâ”€â”€ lib/                # Utilities (firebase.ts, env.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ pages/              # Page components (Dashboard.tsx, Login.tsx)
â”œâ”€â”€ store/              # Zustand stores (authStore.ts, appStore.ts)
â”œâ”€â”€ test/               # Test utilities and setup
â””â”€â”€ types/              # TypeScript type definitions
```

### Testing Infrastructure
- **Vitest** - Unit testing with React Testing Library
- **Playwright** - E2E testing across browsers 
- **Storybook** - Component development and visual testing
- Configured for 90%+ test coverage targets
- Test single file: `npm test -- specific-component.test.tsx`
- Run specific E2E test: `npm run test:e2e -- --grep "test name"`

### Environment Configuration
- Uses type-safe environment validation via `src/lib/env.ts`
- Supports both Firebase emulators and real Firebase projects
- Set `VITE_USE_EMULATOR=true` for local development (default)

### Firebase Emulator Setup
- **Auth**: Port 9099
- **Firestore**: Port 8088  
- **Functions**: Port 5001
- **UI**: Port 4000 (management interface)

### Key Features
- Automatic Firebase emulator connection in development
- Type-safe environment variable handling
- Comprehensive error handling with user-friendly messages
- Real-time Firestore integration
- Responsive design with dark/light mode support
- CI/CD ready with GitHub Actions workflows

### Development Workflow
This project follows a structured development approach:
1. Architecture-first design with system documentation
2. MVP slicing with iterative delivery
3. Automatic feedback via CI/CD
4. Test-driven development for critical paths

### Important Notes
- Always run tests and lint before committing
- Use Firebase emulators for development to avoid affecting production data
- Follow the existing TypeScript strict mode conventions
- Components should include tests and Storybook stories
- Environment variables are validated on startup

Research Agent = This Agend is activated parallel to the planning agent, he researches all the documentation that is needed for the project the user has descibed and that the planning agent has developed. The agent uses the firecrawl MCP to scrape the whole documentation, summerize it and deliver it to the coding other agents in the most efficient format. 3.) Backend Agent = The Backend Agnet is a specialist for backend developing in th eframework of this template (firebase & typescript). He uses the plan of the planning agent, and the documentation of the research agent and builds the backend according to the templates workflow definition and rules. 4.) frontend Agent = the fronent agent is a speciliast for buidling frontend in react, typescript and tailwindCSS with shadcn. Control agent = the control agent is a scrum master for all the other agents. [Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

Custom sub agents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-sub-agents%3F)  What are sub agents?

Sub agents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each sub agent:

- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
- Can be configured with specific tools itâ€™s allowed to use
- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior

When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a sub agentâ€™s expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized sub agent, which works independently and returns results.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits

## Context preservation

Each sub agent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.

## Specialized expertise

Sub agents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.

## Reusability

Once created, sub agents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.

## Flexible permissions

Each sub agent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific sub agent types.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start

To create your first sub agent:

1

Open the sub agents interface

Run the following command:

Copy

```
/agents

```

2

Select 'Create New Agent'

Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level sub agent

3

Define the sub agent

- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
- If youâ€™re generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`

4

Save and use

Your sub agent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:

Copy

```
> Use the code-reviewer sub agent to check my recent changes

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#sub-agent-configuration)  Sub agent configuration

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations

Sub agents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:

| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Project sub agents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
| **User sub agents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |

When sub agent names conflict, project-level sub agents take precedence over user-level sub agents.

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format

Each sub agent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:

Copy

```markdown
---
name: your-sub-agent-name
description: Description of when this sub agent should be invoked
tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
---

Your sub agent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
and should clearly define the sub agent's role, capabilities, and approach
to solving problems.

Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
the sub agent should follow.

```

#### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields

| Field | Required | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the sub agentâ€™s purpose |
| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools

Sub agents can be granted access to any of Claude Codeâ€™s internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.

**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.

You have two options for configuring tools:

- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)

**MCP Tools**: Sub agents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, sub agents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-sub-agents)  Managing sub agents

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)

The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for sub agent management:

Copy

```
/agents

```

This opens an interactive menu where you can:

- View all available sub agents (built-in, user, and project)
- Create new sub agents with guided setup
- Edit existing custom sub agents, including their tool access
- Delete custom sub agents
- See which sub agents are active when duplicates exist
- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management

You can also manage sub agents by working directly with their files:

Copy

```bash
# Create a project sub agent
mkdir -p .claude/agents
echo '---
name: test-runner
description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
---

You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md

# Create a user sub agent
mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
# ... create sub agent file

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-sub-agents-effectively)  Using sub agents effectively

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation

Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:

- The task description in your request
- The `description` field in sub agent configurations
- Current context and available tools

To encourage more proactive sub agent use, include phrases like â€œuse PROACTIVELYâ€ or â€œMUST BE USEDâ€ in your `description` field.

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation

Request a specific sub agent by mentioning it in your command:

Copy

```
> Use the test-runner sub agent to fix failing tests
> Have the code-reviewer sub agent look at my recent changes
> Ask the debugger sub agent to investigate this error

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-sub-agents)  Example sub agents

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer

Copy

```markdown
---
name: code-reviewer
description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
---

You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.

When invoked:
1. Run git diff to see recent changes
2. Focus on modified files
3. Begin review immediately

Review checklist:
- Code is simple and readable
- Functions and variables are well-named
- No duplicated code
- Proper error handling
- No exposed secrets or API keys
- Input validation implemented
- Good test coverage
- Performance considerations addressed

Provide feedback organized by priority:
- Critical issues (must fix)
- Warnings (should fix)
- Suggestions (consider improving)

Include specific examples of how to fix issues.

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger

Copy

```markdown
---
name: debugger
description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
---

You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.

When invoked:
1. Capture error message and stack trace
2. Identify reproduction steps
3. Isolate the failure location
4. Implement minimal fix
5. Verify solution works

Debugging process:
- Analyze error messages and logs
- Check recent code changes
- Form and test hypotheses
- Add strategic debug logging
- Inspect variable states

For each issue, provide:
- Root cause explanation
- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
- Specific code fix
- Testing approach
- Prevention recommendations

Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist

Copy

```markdown
---
name: data-scientist
description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
tools: Bash, Read, Write
---

You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.

When invoked:
1. Understand the data analysis requirement
2. Write efficient SQL queries
3. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
4. Analyze and summarize results
5. Present findings clearly

Key practices:
- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
- Include comments explaining complex logic
- Format results for readability
- Provide data-driven recommendations

For each analysis:
- Explain the query approach
- Document any assumptions
- Highlight key findings
- Suggest next steps based on data

Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices

- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial sub agent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.

- **Design focused sub agents**: Create sub agents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one sub agent do everything. This improves performance and makes sub agents more predictable.

- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the sub agent will perform.

- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the sub agentâ€™s purpose. This improves security and helps the sub agent focus on relevant actions.

- **Version control**: Check project sub agents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.


## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-sub-agents)  Chaining sub agents

For complex workflows, you can chain multiple sub agents:

Copy

```
> First use the code-analyzer sub agent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer sub agent to fix them

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-sub-agent-selection)  Dynamic sub agent selection

Claude Code intelligently selects sub agents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations

- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
- **Latency**: Sub agents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation

- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

Custom sub agents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-sub-agents%3F)  What are sub agents?

Sub agents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each sub agent:

- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
- Can be configured with specific tools itâ€™s allowed to use
- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior

When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a sub agentâ€™s expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized sub agent, which works independently and returns results.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits

## Context preservation

Each sub agent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.

## Specialized expertise

Sub agents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.

## Reusability

Once created, sub agents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.

## Flexible permissions

Each sub agent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific sub agent types.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start

To create your first sub agent:

1

Open the sub agents interface

Run the following command:

Copy

```
/agents

```

2

Select 'Create New Agent'

Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level sub agent

3

Define the sub agent

- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
- If youâ€™re generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`

4

Save and use

Your sub agent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:

Copy

```
> Use the code-reviewer sub agent to check my recent changes

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#sub-agent-configuration)  Sub agent configuration

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations

Sub agents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:

| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Project sub agents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
| **User sub agents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |

When sub agent names conflict, project-level sub agents take precedence over user-level sub agents.

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format

Each sub agent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:

Copy

```markdown
---
name: your-sub-agent-name
description: Description of when this sub agent should be invoked
tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
---

Your sub agent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
and should clearly define the sub agent's role, capabilities, and approach
to solving problems.

Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
the sub agent should follow.

```

#### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields

| Field | Required | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the sub agentâ€™s purpose |
| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools

Sub agents can be granted access to any of Claude Codeâ€™s internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.

**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.

You have two options for configuring tools:

- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)

**MCP Tools**: Sub agents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, sub agents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-sub-agents)  Managing sub agents

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)

The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for sub agent management:

Copy

```
/agents

```

This opens an interactive menu where you can:

- View all available sub agents (built-in, user, and project)
- Create new sub agents with guided setup
- Edit existing custom sub agents, including their tool access
- Delete custom sub agents
- See which sub agents are active when duplicates exist
- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management

You can also manage sub agents by working directly with their files:

Copy

```bash
# Create a project sub agent
mkdir -p .claude/agents
echo '---
name: test-runner
description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
---

You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md

# Create a user sub agent
mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
# ... create sub agent file

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-sub-agents-effectively)  Using sub agents effectively

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation

Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:

- The task description in your request
- The `description` field in sub agent configurations
- Current context and available tools

To encourage more proactive sub agent use, include phrases like â€œuse PROACTIVELYâ€ or â€œMUST BE USEDâ€ in your `description` field.

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation

Request a specific sub agent by mentioning it in your command:

Copy

```
> Use the test-runner sub agent to fix failing tests
> Have the code-reviewer sub agent look at my recent changes
> Ask the debugger sub agent to investigate this error

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-sub-agents)  Example sub agents

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer

Copy

```markdown
---
name: code-reviewer
description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
---

You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.

When invoked:
1. Run git diff to see recent changes
2. Focus on modified files
3. Begin review immediately

Review checklist:
- Code is simple and readable
- Functions and variables are well-named
- No duplicated code
- Proper error handling
- No exposed secrets or API keys
- Input validation implemented
- Good test coverage
- Performance considerations addressed

Provide feedback organized by priority:
- Critical issues (must fix)
- Warnings (should fix)
- Suggestions (consider improving)

Include specific examples of how to fix issues.

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger

Copy

```markdown
---
name: debugger
description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
---

You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.

When invoked:
1. Capture error message and stack trace
2. Identify reproduction steps
3. Isolate the failure location
4. Implement minimal fix
5. Verify solution works

Debugging process:
- Analyze error messages and logs
- Check recent code changes
- Form and test hypotheses
- Add strategic debug logging
- Inspect variable states

For each issue, provide:
- Root cause explanation
- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
- Specific code fix
- Testing approach
- Prevention recommendations

Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist

Copy

```markdown
---
name: data-scientist
description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
tools: Bash, Read, Write
---

You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.

When invoked:
1. Understand the data analysis requirement
2. Write efficient SQL queries
3. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
4. Analyze and summarize results
5. Present findings clearly

Key practices:
- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
- Include comments explaining complex logic
- Format results for readability
- Provide data-driven recommendations

For each analysis:
- Explain the query approach
- Document any assumptions
- Highlight key findings
- Suggest next steps based on data

Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.

```

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices

- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial sub agent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.

- **Design focused sub agents**: Create sub agents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one sub agent do everything. This improves performance and makes sub agents more predictable.

- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the sub agent will perform.

- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the sub agentâ€™s purpose. This improves security and helps the sub agent focus on relevant actions.

- **Version control**: Check project sub agents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.


## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-sub-agents)  Chaining sub agents

For complex workflows, you can chain multiple sub agents:

Copy

```
> First use the code-analyzer sub agent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer sub agent to fix them

```

### [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-sub-agent-selection)  Dynamic sub agent selection

Claude Code intelligently selects sub agents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations

- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
- **Latency**: Sub agents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

## [â€‹](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation

- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers

	â€¢	Vercel preview linked.
	6.	Merge â†’ Staging
	â€¢	Successful build deploys automatically.
	â€¢	E2E smoke test (Playwright).
	7.	Retro + Knowledge Capture
	â€¢	LLM summarizes PR discussion + errors as â€œlearningâ€ in ledger.md.
	â€¢	Weekly Anki cards from ledger.

â¸»

4. Using LLMs Without Context Loss

Problem	Countermeasure
LLM â€œforgetsâ€ code and generates inconsistencies.  ï¿¼	â€¢ context.ts contains: tech stack, naming conventions, DB schema.â€¢ Every prompt references commit hash + file path.
Missing documentation consistency.  ï¿¼	â€¢ PR merge hook triggers script that updates docs/ (doc-as-code).
Progress not traceable.  ï¿¼	â€¢ Ledger automation: GitHub Action pushes task status + timestamp into ledger.md.


â¸»

5. Debugging & Quality
	â€¢	TDD-lite: Write tests only for â€œhot pathsâ€ + bug reproductions.
	â€¢	LLM stack-trace prompt: â€œYou are a TS compiler. Explain line X and suggest a fix.â€
	â€¢	Remote REPL: node --inspect â†’ Chrome DevTools.
	â€¢	Observability: Vercel + Supabase logs; on error mail via Postgres function.

â¸»

6. Learning Cycle & Knowledge Base

Phase	Method	Tool
Daily	5 min ledger.md review	VS Code / Cursor
Weekly	Retro + successes & blockers	GitHub Discussion
Monthly	Consolidated â€œaha momentsâ€ in Anki deck	AnkiConnect
Ongoing	Automatic RAG: code + docs in Chroma	agents/rag.ts


â¸»

7. First To-Dos for Consolidation Phase (0-4 weeks)
	1.	Clone + adapt template repo (1 day)
	2.	Migrate current favorite side project
	â€¢	Only core feature as first MVP.
	3.	Automate CI/CD & ledger
	4.	Implement LLM context helpers
	5.	Establish Anki workflow (weekly 10 cards)

Tip: Start with a deliberately tiny end-to-end slice (e.g. â€œUser can create & view taskâ€). Go through all 7 workflow steps in 1-2 days â€“ then adjust.

â¸»

8. Whatâ€™s next?

If you want, I can create a canvas document with templates for:
	â€¢	Architecture one-pager
	â€¢	PR template
	â€¢	Ledger structure
	â€¢	Example CI workflow

So you can adapt the plan live without losing it in chat. Just say the word!

# Template Development Workflow

This template follows a structured 7-step development process with comprehensive testing and LLM integration. **Follow this workflow for best results.**

## Step 1: Project Planning & Documentation
- **ALWAYS start with documentation before code**
- Create/update [docs/01_project_brief.md](mdc:docs/01_project_brief.md) with Lean Canvas approach
- Create/update [docs/02_architecture.md](mdc:docs/02_architecture.md) with technical decisions
- Create/update [docs/03_backlog.md](mdc:docs/03_backlog.md) with atomic tasks
- **Use LLM context system** for documentation generation
- **Rule**: No coding until documentation is complete

## Step 2: Type-First Development
- **ALWAYS define types before components**
- Start with [src/types/](mdc:src/types/) directory
- Define all interfaces, types, and API contracts first
- **Use RAG system** to find similar type patterns
- **Rule**: Every component must have proper TypeScript types

## Step 3: State Management Setup
- Use Zustand for state management in [src/store/](mdc:src/store/)
- Create stores before UI components
- Follow pattern: `authStore.ts`, `dataStore.ts`, `uiStore.ts`
- **Write unit tests** for store logic
- **Rule**: State management comes before UI implementation

## Step 4: Component Architecture with Testing
- Build components in this order:
  1. **Component interface** and types
  2. **Storybook story** for component variants
  3. **Unit tests** for component behavior
  4. **Component implementation**
  5. **Integration tests** if needed
- **Create components** in [src/components/](mdc:src/components/)
- **Page-level components** in [src/pages/](mdc:src/pages/)
- **Rule**: Test-driven component development

## Step 5: API Integration with Testing
- Create API clients in [src/lib/](mdc:src/lib/)
- Use Firebase Functions for secure backend operations
- **Write unit tests** for API clients
- **Mock external dependencies** in tests
- **Add E2E tests** for critical flows
- **Rule**: API integration after UI is functional with mock data

## Step 6: Comprehensive Testing & Quality Assurance
- **Unit tests** for all components (aim for 90%+ coverage)
- **E2E tests** for critical user journeys
- **Storybook stories** for all components
- **Visual regression testing** through Storybook
- **Performance testing** and optimization
- **Rule**: All quality gates must pass

## Step 7: Deployment & Monitoring
- **Deploy to staging** environment first
- **Run full test suite** in production-like environment
- **Monitor performance** metrics
- **Update documentation** with learnings
- **Rule**: No production deployment without staging validation

## ğŸ”§ Available Tools

### Implemented
- **Testing**: Vitest, Playwright, Storybook
- **State**: Zustand stores
- **LLM**: Context management system
- **Environment**: Validated configuration
- **Firebase**: Auth, Firestore, Functions

### Planned (Not Yet Available)
- Knowledge extraction
- Learning analytics
- Retrospective automation
- Ledger tracking
- Anki integration

## ğŸ“‹ Workflow Best Practices

1. **Documentation First**: Always document before coding
2. **Type Safety**: Define types before implementation
3. **Test Coverage**: Write tests alongside code
4. **Code Review**: Use LLM context for assistance
5. **Incremental Delivery**: Small, tested changes

## âš ï¸ Important Notes

- Some advanced features mentioned in documentation are planned but not yet implemented
- Focus on the core workflow and available tools
- The template provides a solid foundation for building production-ready applications

# Tech Stack & Architecture Rules

**NEVER deviate from this tech stack.** These decisions are final and proven.

## Frontend Stack (MANDATORY)
- **React 19+** with TypeScript
- **Vite** for build tooling (never Webpack/CRA)
- **Tailwind CSS** for styling (no CSS-in-JS, no styled-components)
- **Zustand** for state management (never Redux/Context API for complex state)
- **React Router** for routing
- **@dnd-kit** for drag and drop functionality

## Backend Stack (MANDATORY)
- **Firebase** as primary backend
  - **Firebase Auth** for authentication
  - **Firestore** for database
  - **Firebase Functions** for serverless backend
- **Node.js 18+** for Functions runtime

## Testing Stack (MANDATORY)
- **Vitest** for unit testing (never Jest)
- **React Testing Library** for component testing
- **Playwright** for E2E testing across multiple browsers
- **Storybook** for component development and visual testing
- **@storybook/addon-vitest** for Storybook test integration

## Development Tools (MANDATORY)
- **TypeScript** strict mode enabled
- **ESLint** with standard config + Storybook rules
- **Prettier** for code formatting
- **Git** with conventional commits
- **GitHub Actions** for CI/CD automation

## LLM Context Management (MANDATORY)
- **Prompt Templates** in [src/agents/prompt_helpers.ts](mdc:src/agents/prompt_helpers.ts)
- **RAG System** in [src/agents/rag_system.ts](mdc:src/agents/rag_system.ts)
- **Project Context** in [src/agents/context.ts](mdc:src/agents/context.ts)
- **Context Extraction** utilities for code analysis

## Project Structure (ENFORCED)
```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ components/     # Reusable UI components
â”œâ”€â”€ pages/         # Route-level components
â”œâ”€â”€ store/         # Zustand stores
â”œâ”€â”€ types/         # TypeScript definitions
â”œâ”€â”€ lib/           # Utilities and API clients
â”œâ”€â”€ assets/        # Static assets
â”œâ”€â”€ agents/        # LLM context management
â””â”€â”€ test/          # Test utilities and setup

docs/              # All documentation
â”œâ”€â”€ 01_project_brief.md
â”œâ”€â”€ 02_architecture.md
â””â”€â”€ 03_backlog.md

functions/         # Firebase Functions
â””â”€â”€ src/

tests/             # E2E tests
â””â”€â”€ e2e/

.github/           # CI/CD workflows
â””â”€â”€ workflows/
    â”œâ”€â”€ ci.yml
    â”œâ”€â”€ test.yml
    â””â”€â”€ storybook-deploy.yml

.storybook/        # Storybook configuration
```

## Code Standards (ENFORCED)
- **100% TypeScript** - no JavaScript files
- **Functional components only** - no class components
- **Custom hooks** for reusable logic
- **Error boundaries** for all major components
- **Loading states** for all async operations
- **Comprehensive testing** for all components

## Testing Requirements (MANDATORY)
- **Unit tests** for all components in `*.test.tsx` files
- **E2E tests** for critical user flows
- **Storybook stories** for all components in `*.stories.tsx` files
- **90%+ test coverage** target
- **Visual regression testing** through Storybook

## API Integration Rules
- **Firebase Functions** for all external API calls
- **Never expose API keys** in frontend
- **Always encrypt sensitive data** before Firestore storage
- **Comprehensive error handling** with user-friendly messages
- **Optimistic updates** with rollback on failure

## Styling Rules
- **Tailwind CSS only** - no custom CSS files except globals
- **Mobile-first responsive design**
- **Dark mode support** using Tailwind dark: variants
- **Consistent spacing** using Tailwind spacing scale
- **Accessibility compliance** (WCAG 2.1 AA)

## State Management Rules
- **Zustand stores** in [src/store/](mdc:src/store/)
- **One store per domain** (auth, data, UI)
- **Actions co-located** with state
- **TypeScript interfaces** for all store shapes
- **Optimistic updates** for better UX

## LLM Context Management Rules
- **Use prompt templates** from [src/agents/prompt_helpers.ts](mdc:src/agents/prompt_helpers.ts)
- **Leverage RAG system** for code context retrieval
- **Maintain project context** in [src/agents/context.ts](mdc:src/agents/context.ts)
- **Extract context** for code analysis and documentation
- **Generate context-aware prompts** for development tasks

## CI/CD Rules (MANDATORY)
- **All commits** trigger CI pipeline
- **Pull requests** require passing tests
- **Main branch** protected with status checks
- **Automated deployment** to staging/production
- **Test coverage** reporting required
- **E2E tests** must pass before merge

1â†’# Documentation-First Development
     2â†’
     3â†’**NEVER start coding without proper documentation.** This rule is non-negotiable.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Documentation Hierarchy (MANDATORY)
     6â†’
     7â†’### 1. Project Brief ([docs/01_project_brief.md](mdc:docs/01_project_brief.md))
     8â†’**MUST be created first.** Contains:
     9â†’- Problem statement and solution
    10â†’- Target users and use cases
    11â†’- Key metrics and success criteria
    12â†’- Unique value proposition
    13â†’- Revenue model (if applicable)
    14â†’- Cost structure
    15â†’- Unfair advantage
    16â†’
    17â†’### 2. Architecture Document ([docs/02_architecture.md](mdc:docs/02_architecture.md))
    18â†’**MUST be created before any code.** Contains:
    19â†’- Data model with relationships
    20â†’- Core user flow diagrams
    21â†’- Tech stack decisions with justifications
    22â†’- Key design decisions
    23â†’- Security considerations
    24â†’- Performance considerations
    25â†’
    26â†’### 3. Backlog ([docs/03_backlog.md](mdc:docs/03_backlog.md))
    27â†’**MUST break down ALL work into atomic tasks.** Contains:
    28â†’- MVP scope definition
    29â†’- Atomic tasks (3-8 hours each)
    30â†’- Task dependencies
    31â†’- Definition of done for each task
    32â†’- Progress tracking
    33â†’
    34â†’## Documentation Standards
    35â†’
    36â†’### Task Breakdown Rules
    37â†’- **Maximum 8 hours per task** - if longer, break it down further
    38â†’- **Clear dependencies** - what must be done before this task
    39â†’- **Specific deliverables** - exactly what will be created
    40â†’- **Acceptance criteria** - how to know the task is complete
    41â†’
    42â†’### Progress Tracking
    43â†’- **Update documentation** as you complete tasks
    44â†’- **Mark dependencies** when they're satisfied
    45â†’- **Document decisions** and rationale

# Documentation-First Development

**NEVER start coding without proper documentation.** This rule is non-negotiable.

## Documentation Hierarchy (MANDATORY)

### 1. Project Brief ([docs/01_project_brief.md](mdc:docs/01_project_brief.md))
**MUST be created first.** Contains:
- Problem statement and solution
- Target users and use cases
- Key metrics and success criteria
- Unique value proposition
- Revenue model (if applicable)
- Cost structure
- Unfair advantage

### 2. Architecture Document ([docs/02_architecture.md](mdc:docs/02_architecture.md))
**MUST be created before any code.** Contains:
- Data model with relationships
- Core user flow diagrams
- Tech stack decisions with justifications
- Key design decisions
- Security considerations
- Performance considerations

### 3. Backlog ([docs/03_backlog.md](mdc:docs/03_backlog.md))
**MUST break down ALL work into atomic tasks.** Contains:
- MVP scope definition
- Atomic tasks (3-8 hours each)
- Task dependencies
- Definition of done for each task
- Progress tracking

## Documentation Standards

### Task Breakdown Rules
- **Maximum 8 hours per task** - if longer, break it down further
- **Clear dependencies** - what must be done before this task
- **Specific deliverables** - exactly what will be created
- **Acceptance criteria** - how to know the task is complete

### Progress Tracking
- **Update documentation** as you complete tasks
- **Mark dependencies** when they're satisfied
- **Document decisions** and rationale
- **Track blockers** and their resolution

## Code Documentation Requirements

### README.md (MANDATORY)
Must contain:
- Project description and purpose
- Setup instructions (step-by-step)
- Development workflow
- Deployment instructions
- Troubleshooting guide

### API Documentation
- **Every API endpoint** must be documented
- **Request/response examples** for all endpoints
- **Error codes and messages** with explanations
- **Authentication requirements**

### Component Documentation
```typescript
/**
 * ArticleCard - Displays an article with drag-and-drop functionality
 * 
 * @param article - The article data to display
 * @param onMove - Callback when article is moved to a category
 * @param onDelete - Callback when article is deleted
 * @param isDragging - Whether the card is currently being dragged
 * 
 * @example
 * <ArticleCard 
 *   article={article} 
 *   onMove={handleMove}
 *   onDelete={handleDelete}
 * />
 */
```

## Live Documentation Rules

### Keep Documentation Current
- **Update docs immediately** when implementation changes
- **Never let docs get stale** - they must reflect current reality
- **Document decisions** as you make them
- **Explain "why" not just "what"**

### Setup Guides
- **Step-by-step instructions** that anyone can follow
- **Prerequisites clearly listed**
- **Troubleshooting sections** for common issues
- **Screenshots or examples** where helpful

### API Integration Guides
- **Clear setup instructions** for external services
- **Configuration examples** with placeholder values
- **Error handling documentation** with solutions
- **Testing instructions** to verify setup

## Documentation-Driven Development Process

### Before Starting Any Feature
1. **Document the feature** in the backlog
2. **Define acceptance criteria** clearly
3. **Identify dependencies** and prerequisites
4. **Create user flow diagrams** if complex
5. **Only then start coding**

### During Development
1. **Update documentation** as you learn
2. **Document decisions** and trade-offs
3. **Keep README current** with setup changes
4. **Document new configuration** requirements

### After Completing Feature
1. **Update all relevant docs** to reflect changes
2. **Add troubleshooting info** for issues encountered
3. **Document testing procedures**
4. **Mark tasks complete** in backlog

## Quality Gates

### No Code Without Docs
- **Every PR must include** documentation updates
- **No feature is complete** without documentation
- **Setup instructions must work** for new developers

### Documentation Review
- **All documentation** must be reviewed for accuracy
- **Setup instructions** must be tested by someone else
- **API docs** must match actual implementation
